text.value: The following passage is a jumbled version of lines spoken by Hamlet at the end of Act I. Touch / click and move each line to recreate the text in its correct order:

reveal.value: The flourish of a rhyming couplet will often round off the last speech of an important scene.

value.value: With all my love I do commend me to you:
And what so poor a man as Hamlet is
May do, to express his love and friending to you,
God willing, shall not lack. Let us go in together;
The time is out of joint: O cursed spite,
That ever I was born to set it right!
And still your fingers on your lips, I pray.
